text: The submitters have raised particular concerns in relation to the potential loss of privacy. In particular, the submitters at 107 Taylor Street have stated that there will be a total of 20 windows overlooking their property. In my opinion, the statement is misleading as the windows located on the ground floor will not be visible from the property due to the 1.8 metre high fence and the landscaping that is proposed along the internal boundary.  Of the upper level windows, which there are 10, three of the windows will be bathrooms, which will contain opaque glass, which cannot be seen through.  Notwithstanding, in order to further mitigate any potential effects on the owners and occupiers at 107 Taylor Street, the applicant is happy to explore the potential for a higher internal fence. This was not offered up as part of the original application as it would result in a further non-compliance with the district plan standards.  It is important to note that this measure would be voluntary mitigation offered up and would not have any bearing on the overall conclusions reached in this report in relation to the potential privacy effects.  It was also noted that the proposed landscaping identified in a professional landscape design plan prepared by, and I've got line seven design, so it's important to know that a yachting company didn't do the landscaping. It was actually Line N Design, who are a very well-known local landscaping company. So that's all the peripheries of the site, and it will soften the bulk of the dwellings.

text: Can you hear me OK, though? Is it right? OK. Actually, my paper was actually sitting on the microphone, so I'll move that.  Accentuating and maximizing privacy in the neighboring properties was a key discussion point during the design phase of the project. As such, the development was designed so the upper levels of the dwellings were recessed off the boundary to maximize the separation distance between the units and the adjoining properties.  It is important to note that there are no district plan provisions that restrict the number of windows that could be constructed on the exterior facade of a building. For example, a dwelling exactly the same size as what is proposed when viewed from the boundaries of 107 Taylor Street could be constructed as a permitted activity, not requiring resource consent.  This point was also specifically referenced in Council's 42a report as follows.  I agree and also note that the number of windows is typical and generally consistent with what could occur as a permitted activity, specifically noting that the proposed buildings comply with the internal setback and height in relation to boundary requirements of the district plan. Furthermore, two-storey dwellings are anticipated by the district plan and are not uncommon in that area. Therefore, while there may be a perceived loss of privacy,  there is no increased loss of privacy as a result of the two-storey dwellings. Based on the above analysis, I conclude that the proposal will not result in a loss of privacy on the neighbouring properties that has not already been anticipated in the residential environment by virtue of the provisions of the district plan. I'll now talk about shading.  the submitters have raised concerns regarding potential shading effects. The key point to note is that the proposal complies with the height in relation to boundary provisions of the plan, of the district plan. Thus, once again, dwelling exactly the same height and the same location could be constructed as a permitted activity, not requiring resource consent.  As such, we're able to conclude that the proposal does not generate any additional shading effects over and above what has been anticipated and permitted in the residential zone. I'd like to now talk about the failure to comply with district plan provisions. It is acknowledged that the proposal fails to comply with a number of district plan provisions and ultimately defaults to a non-complying activity.  However, the journey towards the proposal defaults to a non-complying activity is worth further analysis. As identified in Council's 42A report, compact housing within the compact housing overlay is initially assessed as a restricted discretionary activity. However, since the site vows to comply with a 2,000 metre squared minimum lot size, the land use component of the proposal defaults to a discretionary activity.  The only reason the application defaults to a non-compliant activity is due to the corresponding freehold subdivision. Thus, if the application did not seek a concurrent subdivision, the discretionary activity status would remain intact. Council's 42A report also recognises the significance of activity status. And I'll just paraphrase this subsection from the 42A report, because I think it is quite important.  In terms of the site failing to meet the 2000m2 minimum area of Rule 2.4.2.43, it is important to note that this failure results in the proposal being considered a discretionary activity rather than a restricted discretionary activity should the proposal meet the other matters within the rule. This discretionary activity status indicates that the district plan contemplates compact housing that may not meet the restricted discretionary activity requirement.  If a more stringent activity status, such as a non-compliant, such as non-compliant, applied to the proposal that did not meet the minimum area would set a clear discretion, direction that the proposal inconsistent or not participate in the district plan. I concur with the statement from Council's 42A report.  The submitters have identified the Kerrmool surface area as a key non-compliance with the district plan. Whilst I acknowledge that this non-compliance exists, it is important to understand why Kerrmool surface provisions of the district plan were introduced. And that was to give council a degree of discretion to ensure a proposal or activity does not generate any additional stormwater or flooding effects.  As part of the application process, an engineering assessment and design was provided by Titus Consulting Engineers, which provided a proposed solution for the disposal of stormwater. The same report was also reviewed by Council's Development Engineer, who is satisfied the proposed design complies with the appropriate standards and will not have any effect or will not affect the adjoining neighbours.  Based on the findings of the Titus report and the specialist comments made by council's development engineer, I'm satisfied that the proposal will not contribute to any adverse flooding or stormwater effects, including the historic flooding issues on Taylor Street. In conclusion, the provisions of the district plan are an anticipated level of acceptance, which provides a threshold for development to occur as a right.  Where development fails to comply with the provisions of the district plan, it simply allows council or the decision maker the ability to exercise discretion as to the acceptability of such a development through a resource consent process. If a development fails certain provisions of the district plan, it is by no means a prerequisite for a resource consent to be refused.  If that was the case, I wouldn't have a job and all the other planners attending the hearing today wouldn't have a job as well. I'll now move on to amenity. Amenity-related values were comprehensively assessed as part of the application for resource consent and Council's 42a report where it was concluded that the development of this nature has been anticipated on residential sites adjoining reserves  by virtue of the objectives and policies of the district plan, the compact housing overlay, and the key principles of the NPSUD. A very similar conclusion was reached in Council's 42A report, which I concur with. I'd just also, in the next part here, I'd like to paraphrase a key extract from the 42A reports. Once again, I think it provides some quite good context.  It is noted that this type of development is the first of its kind to occur along Taylor Street, which will indicate that it will look slightly different to that of a standard residential development largely comprising of single storey housing existing along that street. However, given the district plan provisions and further direction from central government to establish higher density housing,  The proposal represents a snapshot into the future development that will exist in time along Taylor Street, whilst not compromising the existing amenity values. Overall, it was concluded that the proposal represents an acceptable outcome for the site. And at this point now, I would like to pass on to Mr. Behr, who will just elaborate a bit further  on the design characteristics and the amenity values of the proposal. And I'm also going to turn up the air conditioning because it's freezing really here.

text: Good morning, everyone. Thanks for that, Gareth. I'm Chris Fairman. I've been here from Cambridge. I was approached by Wendy Warren about a year ago to look at the design for this property. Gareth has covered  quite a lot in relation to the building and the shape of the building and the massing and their relationships to the site. So thanks, Gareth. And what I'll cover now, I'll just assume that everyone's read my evidence, and now I'll just cover a few kind of key points from it around the design of the building and sort of the basis for design decisions.  We were quite excited to design this development within a compact housing overlay. It's kind of a  For Cambridge, it's something that Cambridge is looking at more and more, and there are a few around in Cambridge, but we wanted to design something that worked as kind of a good example for what might be developed in the future. We looked at the site in conjunction with Gareth and determined that sort of a site density of one dwelling per 200 square meters was reasonable and suitable, both for the site  the area of the site, but also in relation to compact housing and what sort of density might be suitable, I guess, for the community and the town going forward. The design of the buildings on that density was five buildings on the site. We looked at minimising the driveway and the crossing so we'd have less  impact on the surroundings. We also looked at configuring the dwellings so that they had good-sized outdoor living areas, that the living areas, kitchen, dining, were on the ground floor, and that the upper floors housed the bedrooms, and that the upper floors were sort of pulled back from the boundaries so the buildings had less sort of overall mass from the outside and less effect on neighboring properties.  We made a decision to design within all the building setbacks and within the daylight plan, hypercession plans. And then we further made a decision to configure the overall development of the dwellings into two forms. So there's two dwellings at the back that are in one building form and three in the front that are in one building form. And the idea was that  was to sort of continue the typology of the area and Gareth covered a bit of this in his evidence in terms of  building something that might be able to be seen as a typical development where a similar sized section is subdivided into two properties and there's two dwellings built on the site. So that was something that was quite important to us. In terms of the appearance of the buildings, we worked quite closely with Wendy and Warren, and they'll talk a little bit about this, but the outside quality  and appearance was very important. And so we've looked at using materials that sort of represent that high quality. And quite a lot of emphasis put on landscaping, both kind of the communal landscaping around the driveways and the street frontage, but also within the dwellings themselves. And so there's a big emphasis on building these buildings that are  sort of a high quality that I guess the overall thing is that they're a good example of what compact housing can be in this area. And that's essentially design. I think I'm happy to take questions as well, but I'll hand over back to Kara.
speaker: wendy

The conclusions made within the application for the resource consent also remain relevant. In summary, both reports have drawn the same key conclusions as follows. The proposal represents an acceptable outcome in the residential environment and close proximity to a reserve. The proposal generates a number of positive effects, such as the creation of additional dwellings, providing a mixture of housing typologies,  increased vibrancy of the area. The proposal is not contrary to the objectives and policies of the district plan, but the proposal aligns with the high-level planning documents, in particular the NPSUD, as concluded in Council's section 42a report as follows. In my view, the proposal represents an alternative housing type that can be appropriately serviced and accessible to recreation activities. On this basis, the proposal aligns and gives effect to the NPSUD.  The proposal is in accordance with Part 2, Principles and Purposes of the Act. The proposal passes through both limbs of the Section 104D Gateway Test. And I see there's a typo in there, sorry. It's not the Section 1041D Gateway Test. Based on the above rationale, I conclude the proposal satisfies the required RMA statutory framework, and thus consent is able to be granted. text: Thank you, Mr. Chairperson. Needless to say, good morning, everyone. My name is Christopher James.  and I live at 107 Taylor Street, Cambridge. And needless to say, I have quite a different opinion from the applicants regarding this development. My wife, Helen and I have lived here for nine and a half years. It is our home. We've put a lot of time and effort into making it a pleasant place to live. And we're very concerned about the effect of this development.  The development at 109 Taylor Street is going to have a significant impact on our quality of living and the enjoyment of our section because of the size of the buildings and their proximity to our home. Our house is placed on the eastern side of our section, quite close to the eastern fence line.  This has never been an issue in the past because the driveway of 109 Taylor is on the western side of the section and there's a significant space between the two dwellings. The plan for 109 Taylor is to place the front three terraced houses 1.5 metres from our eastern fence line.  and four meters from the front of the section and along the whole side of our home with another two dwellings at the rear of the section, making five new households with increased noise levels and activity. The plan given to us shows 15 doors and windows looking directly out towards our home and five more looking over our backyard from the western side of the rear dwellings.  This obviously will affect our privacy and the closeness of the two dwellings will create shading issues. Since we were informed of this proposed development, I've made a special effort to observe the shading effects of the buildings. In the morning, a two-storey building would cast a large shadow over our house from the east. And from the early afternoon, our house casts a large shadow over  from, sorry, from in the, right, our house casts a large shadow over the outdoor spaces of anyone living in the new building. I note that there is a 1.8 metre fence planned between the properties, and this may help with some of the privacy issues, but the windows of the dwellings on both sides of the fence will still be a view of each other, and the fence, of course, will do nothing to help with the shading issue.  The notification report concluded that the neighbours of 109 Taylor Street would be affected by this new development. And I note that while there are some two-storey buildings on Taylor Street near 109, they are not as large as what is proposed and are spaced in a typical residential density of one dwelling per 500 square metres.  This proposed development has dwellings of much smaller sites, and it is a noticeable change from the existing character of the area. Now, while the development has been designed to comply with the height and setback standards of the district plan, the proposal is to build two large, two-storey buildings, which will have an effect on privacy and shading of the neighbouring houses.  The proposal involves three three-bedroom units and two two-bedroom units. Therefore, the total number of bedrooms is 13. To compare this with a permitted development consisting of two dwellings on the site would be a six-bedroom dwelling and a seven-bedroom dwelling, which, of course, is not a realistic outcome for this site.  On this basis, the proposal represents an increase in intensity above what would be reasonably expected to occur on that site. As a neighbour living next door to 109 Taylor Street, we could not have reasonably expected a development of such a size to take place on that site because it does not comply with the district plan.  That is why we've been given this opportunity to express our concerns regarding this proposed development. Also, after reading through the notification report and looking over the district plan, I noticed that the proposed development at 109 Taylor Street does not comply with the district plan in a number of ways, some of which are very technical. So I intend to focus on the non-compliance that I consider to be of the greatest concern to us.  Rule number 2.4.2.43, a compact housing within the compact housing area overlay shall have a minimum area of 2000 square metres. The proposed development is on a total site of 1012 square metres, which is a little over half of the required area and therefore fails to comply with the district plan  or the compact housing overlay. B, provision F of rule number 2.4.2.43, a development requires at least 30 percent of the net site shall be made up of permeable surfaces. The proposed development has a total permeable area for the site of 14 percent, less than half, and therefore  does not comply with the district plan. I note here that the council's development engineer states that there will be soak pits on the site. And when there is heavy rain, water may bubble out of the soak pit and run down the drive into the catch pit on the roadside. The engineer assures us that the stormwater system will cope.  But despite what the council engineer says, we know that that catch pit has been unable to cope with heavy rain in the past and has caused flooding. And it is likely that it will be under increased pressure with runoff from 109 Taylor Street and heavy rain. It seems unreasonable to us  that the council expects us to accept a possible increased risk of flooding due to this development. And rule number 15.4.2.6, subdivision within the urban limits shall not create more than two rear lots. This development plans to create four rear lots.  This proposed development does not comply with the district plan. So why is it being considered? Is it supposed to create affordable housing? These terraced houses are going to be very small and I suspect after a discussion we had with the developers and their planner, very expensive. The current house and garage on a quarter acre section was purchased for less than the price that it is anticipated will be asked for these terraced houses.  The current dwelling is an affordable house, and it's going to be removed. I note in the article, Compact Homes Feed Housing Demand, written by Lawrence Gullery and published in the Cambridge edition on the 21st of July, 2021, that the compact homes built at 47 Coleridge Street will be marketed at prices ranging from $850 to over $1 million.  And I understand that these terraced houses will be marketed at a similar price. That is not affordable. So if it's not about affordable housing, is it about the intensification of building? I know that the central government is pushing for greater intensification of building.  But according to an article, Housing Affordability, an Ongoing Challenge for Hamilton, Waipā and Waikato Districts, written by Aaron Lehman and published in Stuff on the 3rd of August this year. This applies to Tier 1 cities such as Auckland, Hamilton, Tauranga, Wellington and Christchurch. There's no mention that this needs to happen in Cambridge. In fact, the article goes on to say,  A newly released report on Hamilton, Waikato and Waipā districts found that there is sufficient land to satisfy demand in the short, medium and long term. And just this morning, I noticed in the Herald, there was an article that states the same sort of thing. So, yes, there will be five dwellings in place of one, but the district plan allows for two dwellings on that site already.  And you only have to drive from Cambridge to Hamilton to see all the land that is already set aside for housing in the coming years. Will an extra few small dwellings make much difference? Why not stick to the district plan and not make our neighbourhood less pleasant? So I ask again, why is this non-complying activity being considered?  Why are the council planners recommending this development go ahead, despite the fact that it doesn't comply with the district plan? When was it decided that the rules stating that a development like this should be built on a 2000 square metre section and is planned for a section roughly half that size with four rear lots instead of two should be discretionary? The district plan is very comprehensive.  and a huge amount of work has been put into its development. It should not be ignored. To allow this development to go ahead could create a precedent, and precedents can cause all kinds of problems when you're trying to plan the managed development of a growing town like Cambridge. In this case, it could indicate that the district plan is just a guide and can be ignored and manipulated.  There is no mandate from the people of Cambridge or the Waipā district for a non-complying development such as this to go ahead.  If the council wants to change the district plan, then they should do it properly with the full knowledge and consent of the people of Waipā. If this is to happen, then council needs to draft up a new district plan, consult, listen, adjust accordingly and publish, not change the district plan by stealth and allow non-compliant developments to go ahead. All we ask is that the council enforce compliance with the district plan  and consider the well-being of the residents currently in the area. We believe that the proposed non-complying district development at 109 Taylor Street should not be allowed to proceed. It does not enhance the local area or the Cambridge Township. All it achieves is financial gain for the developers and I do not understand why the council's officers are supporting it.  It would be easy to put two very comfortable homes on that property that would comply with the district plan and would contribute to the overall pleasantness of the area. After all, the Waipā District Council's mission statement says, to partner the community in promoting the wellbeing of the Waipā District and its people. Finally, I would like to express my gratitude for having the opportunity to have my say about this development.  and I just ask that you consider my arguments carefully. Thank you. Greg Morgan Great.

So I'm also a full member of the New Zealand Planning Institute and have approximately 10 years experience in the field. So my scope of evidence relates to urban design and Mr. Wilson, the processing planner, requested an urban design review of the application, which I undertook in March this year. The review also included a site visit, which was completed on the 12th of March with Tim and you,  who to visit the site. So the design review considers the urban design merits of the proposed application generally broken down into the components of context and character, relationship with the street and form and appearance of buildings, amenity, site access and circulation for vehicles, but also considering pedestrians, landscape design, although I must say I am not a landscape designer. So those comments are generally  fairly general in nature, and then some general commentary on the planning and policy context. I won't go through my full design assessment, as this has been taken into account by Mr. Wilson in his assessment, and there have been no areas of contention highlighted in the evidence presented to you from Mrs. Moran and from the applicant side. So I'll just provide some brief highlights there. I guess just starting off with some  character and context. So the site is located within the compact housing overlay of the Waipā residential zone. So that signals a change, I guess, to the design and appearance of buildings that would be anticipated in those areas. And section 2.13 of the Waipā district plan residential zone talks about the anticipated outcomes there. Whilst this isn't an objective or a policy, it just gives a broad overview of the expectations.  and highlights that different typologies may be expected as part of compact housing development. So that includes duplexes and terrace houses, which is what we are seeing with this application. Generally, the area is comprised of single detached dwellings with some two-story dwellings in the area, a range of architectural forms and styles, I guess, reflecting their age of development and construction throughout the area.  So I guess you're looking at the immediately adjacent buildings, 107 and 111 Taylor Street. The building to the west, so that is 107 has hip roof style, and then the neighbouring to the east, 111's got a variety of roof pitches, and I guess the architectural feature of that is its roof line. There's some quite steep pitches and also some flatter pitches. So you've got some variety, I guess, in the built form across the area. The streetscapes generally defined  by a variety of setbacks, so that the building where it sits on the site in relation to the road front, and that varies quite heavily across Taylor Street, between four and a half and 12 metres. I guess just worth noting that the buildings close to the street are anticipated in that compact housing area. And I guess in terms of relation, sorry, in relation to the materiality of the buildings, the plan reserves discretion over  of development in terms of its facade treatment, proportions, detailing, and the materials and landscape treatment. So as I've mentioned, it's fairly varied along Taylor Street. And the proposal uses a range of materials to break up its bulk and form using a mix of timber weatherboard, profile metal cladding, and brick. So those materials are seen throughout Taylor Street. So I consider those to be appropriate from a material point of view.  So just picking up on the bulk of the proposal. So it's five units across two building footprints, which has been discussed by both the submitters and the applicant. And I think looking at the proposal, the splitting of the five units across two buildings breaks up what would otherwise be a large building if five units were combined and serves to reference the development pattern in the area, which is typically a front  front dwelling and subdivided to provide a rear dwelling on the site. I guess just talking now about the relationship to the streets. So, generally, the development provides a positive interaction with the street frontage. It brings in passive surveillance. So, the idea of eyes on the street, which conveys safety, taking into account the safety principles, which is crime prevention through environmental design. It also  clearly delineates ownership between public and private. So you've got a low wall in the front, stepping up some height to provide some privacy for those units. But generally the surveillance and interaction with that street frontage is considered positive, in my opinion. And then talking very briefly around the amenity and on the site. So the site is  north-facing and the street is north-facing, so north towards Taylor Street. So that provides good access to daylight and sunlight, so sun rising, obviously, east and setting in the west and provides access to, so daylight access to the outdoor living areas in particular, taking into account the shadowing that is inevitable from the adjacent buildings, but both buildings being within the height relation to boundary controls. In my opinion, that's acceptable.  And I think just briefly commenting on the location of those outdoor living areas, west-facing outdoor living obviously gives you the opportunity to use it in a sunny respect in the afternoon rather than the morning. So it's generally considered to be a more pleasant or more usable arrangement on site. So I think that is a positive of the design. I will leave kind of vehicle  to that on the site. And I would also just like to, in terms of landscape design, support the inclusion of a condition that requires the submitted landscape plan to be implemented and maintained throughout the, throughout the site. And I would also just like to, in terms of landscape design, support the inclusion of a condition that requires the submitted landscape plan to be implemented and maintained throughout the site. And I would also just like to, in terms of landscape design,  the lifespan of the development. And I think just talking about that, the landscape design provides some screening on the boundaries. Just picking up the comment from the submitters from 111 Taylor Street around their rear yard. I just note the inclusion of Magnolia Little Gem in the landscape plan on the fence boundary adjacent to their outdoor living area.  These trees can grow to four or five metres, so they will need to be maintained to not be overly large, but they do or should provide some screening benefits in that location. Just quickly, I think, talking about the district plan, compact housing area and the 2000 square metres, from an urban design perspective, you generally use a rule framework like that to facilitate a better design outcome. Typically, larger sites provide you  more flexibility to arrange buildings on a site. And it's a tool to provide, I guess, that screening for development and suggest that bigger sites can be designed more comprehensively. In my opinion, the approach taken on the site creates a good urban form.  splits the five units over two building footprints and the use of articulation of the building facade and the materiality, so the building materials used and the variation in the elevations, so how the building steps in and out, so reduces the bulk and form that you'd see if it was a straight flat facade. So I think  the use of or provision of compact housing in an overlay which is identified for increased density, albeit on a small site anticipated. I think the design outcome is appropriate in that setting. I'm happy to take any questions or answer anything in further detail if that's helpful.

In terms of the 104 assessment and the consistency of proposal against the relevant planning documents, I just highlight that, in my view, I think it is consistent with  the direction of the district plan and the objectives and policies, and as well with the NPS for urban development. text: Thanks, Chris. I just want to touch on that density discussion. Now, look, the site isn't 2,000 metres squared, right? We all accept that.  But hypothetically, if it was or if one down the street was 2,000 metres, a compact housing development becomes a restricted discretionary activity in that area. Now, we've got discretionary activity here, we've got a non-compliant here, restricted discretionary is up here, which is even more  on the direction from Council that developments like that are anticipated in that area. Obviously, you can still notify restricted discretionary consents.  but the chances of notification, I know this realises the generalisation, but the chances of a, say, a discretionary activity being notified is far greater than what a restricted discretionary activity would need to be notified. So that's just, it's not directly relevant to the site, but it's important context to the wider environment.  I want to talk about precedence briefly as well. Now, precedent is a really important factor which can be taken into account in these applications for resource consent. If this application or this site was located two or three streets further away from the reserve, we would not have applied for resource consent.  The reason we've applied for resource consent from this particular site is because it relies heavily on a really key policy or objective of the District Plan 2.3.4.5, which encourages compact housing within close proximity to reserves. Areas outside  this close proximity to reserves will not have the support of this policy. So therefore, a precedent cannot be created for other sites, albeit along Taylor Street. Yes, but it is a compact housing overlay. So it's very important to notice that or to note that.  Also, just in terms of the permeability as well, now, look, I'm, Mr. Coot's covered this off, and I don't want to thrash this out too much longer, but we've got a, we relied on our evidence from Titus to conclude our flooding stormwater effects to a point where we concluded them to be acceptable.
